course.subject: OCES
course.name: Principles and Applications of Environmental Science
course.description: This course aims to provide students with a science background to learn and address the environmental issues caused by humans. Key topics include emerging global, regional and local environmental issues; renewable and non-renewable energy; life-supporting systems of our planet and its biodiversity; atmosphere, air pollution and global climate change; water resources and water pollution; ocean plastics and solid waste management; environmental health and toxicology. Through the course, students will be able to understand fundamental knowledge of the inter-relationship between life and our environment, the characteristics of the environmental sustainability, pollution and monitoring measures, and technologies used in pollution control and remediation.

reviews.author: Snoop Dogg
reviews.title: Seriously don't know why I took this class in the first place!
reviews.comment_content: The content is extremely boring! On top of that class, participation is like 40 percent of the grade. The fact that the content is so dull and students won't come to class, they have such a weird grading scheme where class participation accounts more than finals or midterms specifically.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mostly read from the slides, so no comments on that.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is decent. Around 15-18 percent will get the A range. The mean is relatively high, as many students take this class in hopes of a good grade. If you are good at memorizing PowerPoint slides, you can get an A range if you work hard. Otherwise, be happy with a B range.

reviews.author: Blue science
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are basically about many things in environmental science and it does not go deep into the details so it won't be too hard assuming that you have some science background and attend the lectures. The harder topics are taught by Prof. He.

Refer to other reviews for detailed topics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is fair overall. The professors' accent is not hard to understand and sometimes they would give jokes in class.

For Prof. LI, I think she is the average one. She can explain things clearly but you can't bear sleeping if you are really sleepy in the 9 am class.

For Prof. WU, I think he tells jokes quite often and can keep the class's attention. He teaches biology, and I think I can learn the contents easily even though I didn't study biology in high school.

For Prof. ZHANG, I think she can keep the class's attention just by her voice. The contents are also easy and less controversial (aka boring). Her lecture PowerPoint slides are also pretty.

For Prof. HE, I think his topic is the hardest and I cannot follow the contents at all. Especially the microplastics part. I have no idea what it is about. I cannot focus on his lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation 40%
Midterm Examination 30%
Final Examination 30%

It is obviously very important to attend classes and finish the quizzes given. But they don't take attendance in every class. You would only know whether they take attendance if you go to the lecture.
reviews.comment_workload: You have to do nothing besides attend lectures because all examinations and quizzes are open-book. And you can really find the answers in the lecture PPTs. There are some blanks in the lecture PPTs released but you can remember that from the lectures most of the time.

reviews.author: mading18
reviews.title: Take this course if all you want is free credits, otherwise your time is better spent taking anything else
reviews.comment_content:
The content isn't necessarily hard, it's just very confusing and convoluted, and it is clear that the 4 professors did not properly consult with each other when creating the course curriculum. Some of the content resembles things that are taught in high school biology or chemistry, others teach content that should only be taught in Year 3 OCES major courses. One day the course covers the 4 layers of the atmosphere, the other day the course discusses different methods to identify microplastic fragments.

Rough timeline:
Evolution, biological fitness, genetics
Human influences on environment
Food security and nutrition
Environmental health and toxicology
Water and Air pollution
Energy methods
Solid Waste and Microplastics

These topics absolutely should not be taught in the same course, especially one that was allocated as a Year 1 SSCI foundation course.

For the 3 people who want to declare an OCES major, some of these topics may be valuable to your understanding, especially He's section. Otherwise it's "useless".
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching styles varies greatly every few lectures because 4 professors teach this course. The actual judgement of the quality of the lecturer's teachings really depends on each person's individual opinion for this course, so here's mine. Generally, I don't really have an exceptionally good opinion for any of the professor's teaching; it was mediocre at best and confusing and unnecessary at worst.

Wu (Teaches 33% of the course): Wu covers evolution, genetics, and general biology. Think IB Biology Topics 4 and 5. Wu was by far the best professor during this course; he would explain the content clearly while GIVING EXAMPLES(only lecturer that really "taught" the concepts) while inserting recap slides before each new lecture to remind people of the previous content taught.

Zhang (Teaches 17% of the course): Zhang covers toxic chemicals, different diseases, environmental health, and relations between food production/supply and environment. Her lectures comprise of generic teaching of content that is way harder than anything Wu taught, and the way she delivers this content is just so boring and uninspiring. She just reads her monitor for 1.5 hours and calls it a day. The good thing about her lectures is that her slides literally cover EVERYTHING she talked about in class, so you don't even need to rewatch her lecture videos to understand her portion of the content.

Li (Teaches 27% of the course): Li covers the atmosphere structure and air pollution, water supply, groundwater, water pollution and remediation. Her teaching was fine; she would also put recap of previous lectures at the beginning of each new lecture to allow students to brush up on content

He (Teaches 23% of the course): What the hell, his teaching and the content he taught were an absolute train wreck. He starts off relatively normal with energy methods but then covers oddly specific and convoluted content like solid waste management, microplastic supply and accumulation, and marine environment protection. No, we do NOT want to listen for hours on what your colleague did in Zhejiang, we want you to TEACH THE CLASS. He also chooses content that are far more difficult than the other professors. He also only recites his lecture slides, and he would often skip entire slides or sections because his powerpoints are so long; they are also a nightmare to read through and go over because of how disorganized they were; full of random information that never appeared in the final exam (no joke an entire portion of his oceanography lecture was about James Cameron driving a submarine). As the course coordinator, He's teaching and content that he selected was ironically, by far, the worst. Good luck revising his lectures. By the way, the Kurzgesagt and DW documentary videos he listed as "additional resources" at the end of his lectures taught me more about the content than the lectures itself. SMH, absolute disaster.

Overall, I wouldn't call any of the 4 professors "fascinating" to attend their lectures, maybe Wu was above average but there is definitely room for improvement
reviews.comment_grading:
At least this super boring course has a very generous grading system

30% midterms
30% finals
40% in-class participation/attendance (yes it's true, for a SSCI foundation course)

Midterms and finals comprise of multiple choice questions(both single and multiple choice answers) as a couple of short answer/mini-essay questions. Nothing too complicated.

Midterms and finals are pretty much even in terms of weight, and given that midterms were much easier than finals, the grading system for this course is good.

My scores:
Midterm: 35/40
Final: Unknown
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty much little to no workload without factoring in revision

When 40% of the grade depends on you existing, then the amount of workload you receive in this course is self-explanatory(I didn't even click the box for if quizzes were given in this course because they only check attendance and not even right/wrong answers).
Some instructor's content requires little to no time to revise, others are an absolute pain.

Tip for revision if you have a Mac: Download all the lecture slides, highlight important portions, and command f ever key word per question in the exam, and see that the answers are pretty much GIVEN to you. You’ll have time; they give you 3 whole hours for finals and most were gone by hour 2
